Student volunteers acknowledged during Student Volunteering Week 2023

By James Clay

Plans for future investment in housing and infrastructure are being debated by the local council

UCU strikes stood down

By Gracie Daw

Action on 21, 22, 23, 27, 28 February and 1 and 2 March will not go ahead

YUSU Election Results 2023

By James Clay

Pierrick Roger re-elected as YUSU President

Levene criticised for invasive campaign

David Levene, former Union Council Chair, has come under criticism for violating University policy on campaigning which specifically bans any posters within student halls of residence (Thumbnail credit Levene's campaign used his College connections to gain access to halls)

Ill-timed library closures spark student anger

The University has come under increasing pressure from students after only opening the library for one day out of the four day bank holiday weekend just before exams start and assignments are due in next week (Thumbnail credit Image credit: Peter Iveson)

Liam Burns elected NUS President

Liam Burns has been elected as the new President of the National Union of Students (NUS), succeeding Aaron Porter in the role (Thumbnail credit Liam Burns gained overwhelming victory over other contestants to become the new NUS President. Image credit: www.nus.org.uk)

York runners up in University Challenge final

The University of York are the runners up of this year's University Challenge competition, losing 290 - 85 points to Magdalen College, Oxford (Thumbnail credit Credit: University of York/BBC)

University leaks private details of entire student body

The University of York may be facing serious repercussions after leaking private and personal details of the whole student body (Thumbnail credit The University of York website, through which the data search was made available)

Running against the odds

Camilla Apcar meets first-year Thomas Byrne: this year's surprise candidate for the NUS Presidency (Thumbnail credit Photo: Peter Iveson)

University debt agency accused of intimidation

The University is facing criticism this week, after it has become apparent that the company who deal with all outstanding parking fines on campus have been faced with accusations of harassment and illegal threats to debtors nationally (Thumbnail credit Debt agency Newlyn has sent some students over 30 threatening letters)

YUSU affiliation with NUS questioned

A vote is to be put to the student body by the end of this academic year as to whether or not to continue affiliation with the National Union of Students (NUS)

James College opinions "sidelined" by University in McQ's demolition plans

The likely demolition and relocation of McQ's has resulted in the James Junior Common Room Committee (JCRC) voicing discontent with new proposals for their College bar (Thumbnail credit Designs for the proposed relocation of McQ's bar show its reduced capacity within the Roger Kirk Center. Image: University of York)

Welfare threatened by inadequate security

Students in Fairfax house and Eric Milner A-block have voiced their concerns over current security levels after several burglaries have taken place in recent weeks (Thumbnail credit Students have complained about the level of security on their windows. Photo: Peter Iveson)

Tim Ellis scrapes Presidential win by 14 vote margin

By James Bithell

In what some have termed a surprising result, Tim Ellis has been elected as YUSU President for the year 2011/12 (Thumbnail credit Photo: Philippa Grafton)

First Year hours cut

First year Chemistry students have been left with reduced laboratory hours this year because of the department over-subscribing on the number of applicants. This has led to the number of laboratory hours each week being halved from two days to one in the first year

University increase debt to PS88 million

Financial records have revealed that the University's net debt increased from PS44, 870,000 to PS88,002,000 between 2009/10, showing an almost 100 per cent increase from last year (Thumbnail credit The University's continued expansion on Heslington East of which some of the new debt was used to finance. Photo: George Lowther)

PS100,000 of late library fines

In the last academic year, the University of York's library services collected over one hundred thousand pounds of late return library fines

Union Assembly replaced

There have been significant changes to the proposals for the Democratic Review after a recent Union General Meeting (UGM) which mean that there will be a Democracy Committee instead of the Union Assembly

University will delay fee decision until July

The University has decided not to announce their decision on the new tuition fee level until June or July this year leaving prospective students for 2012 with less time to make higher education decisions (Thumbnail credit Exeter University has already announced its intention to charge PS9,000. Photo: William Veerbeek)

Fusion set to take PS15,000

This year's Fusion 'Playing games' production looks set to have made just under PS15,000 with the opening night alone taking PS4,000 (Thumbnail credit Fusion has made nearly PS15,000 this year but have yet to decide how much will be donated to RAG charities. Photo: Sam Newsome)

Biomass burner plan angers local residents

Badger Hill residents have spoken out against the University's plan to construct a biomass burner on the new Heslington East site voicing concerns about risks to their health

YUSU Election results night: As it happened

Join Nouse at the YUSU elections results party - who will be the winners?

Exit polls show Blundell and Rowley in fight for Presidency

Nouse and YUSU exit polls see Lydia Blundell and Charlie Rowley in battle for Presidency (Thumbnail credit Credit: Pete Iveson. YUSU Presidents at their Hustings night)

York Sport candidates top recognition poll

A recent <em>Nouse</em> election poll has shown that the race for York Sport Presidency have been the most visible so far, with both Asfahani and McGladdery ranking in the top four most recognised candidates (Thumbnail credit York Sport candidates McGladdery and Asfahani have caught the attention of the student body. Image credit: Peter Iveson)

Ziggys evacuation sparks YUSU enquiry

YUSU have confirmed they have launched an investigation after the popular student nightclub Ziggy's was evacuated this Wednesday, following the detonation of a smoke grenade (Thumbnail credit Students gathered outside of Ziggys after being evacuated. Image credit: Rose Troup-Buchanan)

YUSU presidential debate: As it happened

Follow the excitement of the Presidential debate, as <em>Nouse</em> brings you the action as it happens

YUSU Election Hustings: As it happened

<em>Nouse</em> brings you the latest action at YUSU's Election Hustings 2011 (Thumbnail credit Image credit: Peter Iveson)

Mass controversy over visiting Islamic scholar

The invitation of Islamic Scholar Mufti Muhammad ibn Adam al-Kawthari to speak at the University on Wednesday has sparked controversy across campus (Thumbnail credit Mufti Muhammad ibn Adam al-Kawthari delivering a lecture)

YUSU election candidates revealed

The full list of candidates standing in this year's YUSU elections has been released

Council discriminate against students in housing policy

By James Bithell

York's student resident population has been caught up in a political decision which will force rents to rise and discriminate against students attempting to find off-campus housing (Thumbnail credit Data compiled by Nouse from Council records show popular student roads which may suffer the worst rent rises. Graphic: Jonathan Frost)

University to assist with "hidden costs"

Details have recently come to light of the proposed changes to be introduced by the University after the tuition fee increase is implemented (Thumbnail credit If University of York tuition fees are put up to PS9,000 in 2012, each student could be given a free laptop. Photo: Justyn Hardcastle)

Internship company criticised for illicitly recruiting students in lectures

The American internship company, Southwestern, has come under pressure after inappropriately recruiting potential students for their summer internship programme in lectures (Thumbnail credit The Southwestern internship programme have been recruiting in lectures without Departmental permission. Photo: University of York)

Flooded rooms causes disruption for students

Students living in Eric Milner, Block A have voiced their disapprovement with the conditions of their accommodation after three rooms and a main hallway have been flooded (Thumbnail credit James Block N has been without laundry along with Eric Milner Block A. Photo: Peter Iveson)

Levene criticised for invasive campaign

David Levene, former Union Council Chair, has come under criticism for violating University policy on campaigning which specifically bans any posters within student halls of residence (Thumbnail credit Levene's campaign used his College connections to gain access to halls)
